.. codeauthor:: Ludovic Charleux ludovic.charleux@univ-smb.fr

.. code:: ipython3

    import numpy as np
    import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
    import matplotlib as mpl
    import pandas as pd
    %matplotlib nbagg


Theory
======

Scope
-----

-  Widely used in physics
-  Closed form solutions only in particular cases
-  Need for numerical solvers

Ordinary differential equations vs.Â partial differential equation
-----------------------------------------------------------------

Ordinary differential equations (ODE)
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Derivatives of the inknown function only with respect to a single
variable, time :math:`t` for example.

-  Example: 1D harmonic oscillator equation

.. math::


   \dfrac{d^2x}{dt^2} + 2 \zeta \omega_0 \dfrac{dx}{dt} + \omega_0 x = 0

Partial differential equations (PDE)
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Derivatives of the unknown function with respect to several variables,
time :math:`t` and space :math:`(x, y, z)` for example. Special
techniques not introduced in this course need to be used, such as finite
difference or finite elements.

-  Example : the heat equation

.. math::


   \rho C_p \dfrac{\partial T}{\partial t} - k  \Delta T + s = 0

Introductive example
--------------------

Point mass :math:`P` in free fall.

Required data:

-  gravity field :math:`\vec g = (0, -g)`,
-  Mass :math:`m`,
-  Initial position :math:`P_0 = (0, 0)`
-  Initial velocity :math:`\vec V_0 = (v_{x0}, v_{y0})`

Problem formulation:

.. math::


   \left\lbrace \begin{align*}
   \ddot x & = 0\\
   \ddot y & = -g
   \end{align*}\right.

Closed form solution
--------------------

.. math::


   \left\lbrace \begin{align*}
   x(t) &= v_{x0} t\\
   y(t) &= -g \frac{t^2}{2} + v_{y0}t 
   \end{align*}\right.

.. code:: ipython3

    tmax = .2
    t  = np.linspace(0., tmax, 1000) 
    x0, y0   = 0., 0. 
    vx0, vy0 = 1., 1.
    g = 10.
    x = vx0 * t
    y = -g  * t**2/2. + vy0 * t
    fig = plt.figure()
    plt.plot(x, y, label = "Exact solution")
    plt.grid()
    plt.xlabel("Position, $x$")
    plt.ylabel("Position, $y$")
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()




.. parsed-literal::

    <IPython.core.display.Javascript object>



.. raw:: html

    <img src="data:image/png;base64,">


Reformulation
-------------

Any ODEs can be reformulated as a first order system equations. Letâs
assume that:

.. math::


   X = \begin{bmatrix}
   X_0 \\
   X_1 \\
   X_2 \\
   X_3 \\
   \end{bmatrix}
   =
   \begin{bmatrix}
   x \\
   y \\
   \dot x \\
   \dot y \\
   \end{bmatrix}

As a consequence:

.. math::


   \dot X = \begin{bmatrix}
   \dot x \\
   \dot y \\
   \ddot x \\
   \ddot y \\
   \end{bmatrix}

Then, the initialy second order equation can be reformulated as:

.. math::


   \dot X = f(X, t) = 
   \begin{bmatrix}
   X_2 \\
   X_3 \\
   0 \\
   -g \\
   \end{bmatrix}

As a consequence, every ODE can be reformulated in generic way:

.. math::


   \dot X = f(X, t)

Numerical integration of ODE
----------------------------

###Â Generic formulation

.. math::


   \dot X = f(X, t)

-  approximate solution: need for error estimation
-  discrete time: :math:`t_0`, :math:`t_1`, :math:`\ldots`
-  time step :math:`dt = t_{i+1} - t_i`,

Euler method
~~~~~~~~~~~~

-  Intuitive
-  Fast
-  Slow convergence

.. math::


   X_{i+1} = X_i + f(X, t_i) dt

.. code:: ipython3

    dt = 0.005 # Pas de temps
    X0 = np.array([0., 0., vx0, vy0])
    nt = int(tmax/dt) # Nombre de pas
    ti = np.linspace(0., nt * dt, nt)
    
    def derivate(X, t):
        return np.array([X[2], X[3], 0., -g])
    
    def Euler(func, X0, t):
        """
        Euler solver.
        """
        dt = t[1] - t[0]
        nt = len(t)
        X  = np.zeros([nt, len(X0)])
        X[0] = X0
        for i in range(nt-1): X[i+1] = X[i] + func(X[i], t[i]) * dt
        return X
    
    %time X_euler = Euler(derivate, X0, ti)
    x_euler, y_euler = X_euler[:,0], X_euler[:,1]
    
    plt.figure()
    plt.plot(x, y, label = "Exact solution")
    plt.plot(x_euler, y_euler, "or", label = "Euler")
    plt.grid()
    plt.xlabel("x")
    plt.ylabel("y")
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()


.. parsed-literal::

    CPU times: user 0 ns, sys: 0 ns, total: 0 ns
    Wall time: 598 Âµs



.. parsed-literal::

    <IPython.core.display.Javascript object>



.. raw:: html

    <img src="data:image/png;base64,">


Runge Kutta 4
~~~~~~~~~~~~~

`Wikipedia <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Runge%E2%80%93Kutta_methods#Explicit_Runge.E2.80.93Kutta_methods>`__

Evolution of the Euler integrator with:

-  Multiple slope evaluation (4 here),
-  Well chosen weighting to match simple solutions.

.. math::


   X_{i+1} = X_i + \dfrac{dt}{6}\left(k_1 + 2k_2 + 2k_3 + k_4 \right)

With:

-  :math:`k_1` is the increment based on the slope at the beginning of
   the interval, using $ X $ (Eulerâs method);
-  :math:`k_2` is the increment based on the slope at the midpoint of
   the interval, using $ X + dt/2 :raw-latex:`\times `k_1 $;
-  :math:`k_3` is again the increment based on the slope at the
   midpoint, but now using $ X + dt/2:raw-latex:`\times `k_2 $;
-  :math:`k_4` is the increment based on the slope at the end of the
   interval, using $ X + dt :raw-latex:`\times `k_3 $.

.. code:: ipython3

    def RK4(func, X0, t):
        """
        Runge Kutta 4 solver.
        """
        dt = t[1] - t[0]
        nt = len(t)
        X  = np.zeros([nt, len(X0)])
        X[0] = X0
        for i in range(nt-1):
            k1 = func(X[i], t[i])
            k2 = func(X[i] + dt/2. * k1, t[i] + dt/2.)
            k3 = func(X[i] + dt/2. * k2, t[i] + dt/2.)
            k4 = func(X[i] + dt    * k3, t[i] + dt)
            X[i+1] = X[i] + dt / 6. * (k1 + 2. * k2 + 2. * k3 + k4)
        return X
    
    %time X_rk4 = RK4(derivate, X0, ti)
    x_rk4, y_rk4 = X_rk4[:,0], X_rk4[:,1]
    
    plt.figure()
    plt.plot(x, y, label = "Exact solution")
    plt.plot(x_euler, y_euler, "or", label = "Euler")
    plt.plot(x_rk4, y_rk4, "gs", label = "RK4")
    plt.grid()
    plt.xlabel("x")
    plt.ylabel("y")
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()


.. parsed-literal::

    CPU times: user 4 ms, sys: 0 ns, total: 4 ms
    Wall time: 1.98 ms



.. parsed-literal::

    <IPython.core.display.Javascript object>



.. raw:: html

    <img src="data:image/png;base64,">


ODEint (with Scipy)
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Odeint is more sophisticated solved based on the open source Fortran
library **ODEPACK**. It is available in the scientic librairy
``scipy.integrate.odeint``. The documentation can be found
`here <http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy-0.16.0/reference/generated/scipy.integrate.odeint.html>`__.

.. code:: ipython3

    from scipy import integrate
    
    %time X_odeint = integrate.odeint(derivate, X0, ti)
    x_odeint, y_odeint = X_odeint[:,0], X_odeint[:,1]
    
    plt.figure()
    plt.plot(x, y, label = "Exact solution")
    plt.plot(x_euler, y_euler, "or", label = "Euler")
    plt.plot(x_rk4, y_rk4, "gs", label = "RK4")
    plt.plot(x_odeint, y_odeint, "mv", label = "ODEint")
    
    plt.grid()
    plt.xlabel("x")
    plt.ylabel("y")
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()


.. parsed-literal::

    CPU times: user 0 ns, sys: 0 ns, total: 0 ns
    Wall time: 184 Âµs
